questions.query: How does your project create value for the Web3 grants ecosystem?
questions.explanation: The Clinic has the right pilots to give inverted-precedent an appropriate attempt. The repo's forked [README.md](https://github.com/lexclinic/Grants/blob/main/response/README.md).

questions.query: Describe your team's expertise in your chosen focus area within Web3 grants. Include relevant experience, publications, or past projects.
questions.explanation: 2 years running LexDAO's grants. For instance, [this](https://opensea.io/assets/matic/0x440faa25db1ff8685849fc40667d44c8c880cbf2/4600000000000056) $50,000 raise.  Co-created the Grants Committee [here](https://snapshot.org/#/lexdao.eth/proposal/0xc4385c150de0d216acb3c89179ced53917144c207fa040ed81ae7ff83bfb1008) and attempted to innovate on it [here](https://snapshot.org/#/lexgrant.eth) and [here](https://github.com/lexclinic/Grants/blob/main/README.md).

questions.query: How do you plan to share insights, methodologies, or tools developed through your project with the Cartographer Syndicate and the broader Web3 grants community?
questions.explanation: The Journal of Legal Engineering we're spinning up, on [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/@LexClinic) and at our GitHub.

questions.query: What is the desired impact you seek to create through your research, (ie what becomes possible for communities as the result of the research you conduct?)
questions.explanation: [DAO Coalition](https://github.com/daocoa) has developed what we hope can be a basic civics stack by creating modules to connect Hats Protocol with Snapshot, Passport and Unlock Protocol. We would like to do research on this stack as well as the consent innovations we have been doing on Hats mentioned in our project's description. We are helping startup the Journal of Legal Engineering and hope to publish this research there.

questions.query: Please describe your past history conducting research of this nature or the relevant skills that will support your work.
questions.explanation: Ramona has successfully used our students to do research on various topics. Ramona founded and runs one of the houses. Ramona does open collaborative research at RnDAO as well. Kyle has published in Ethereal Forest's first zine and will have finished the first iteration of a legal engineering curriculum by August 12 as that is what he is doing as the legal engineering track lead at ZuVilliage Georgia.

data.name: OpenCivics
data.description:
This OpenCivics Consortium Round seeks to fund critical collaborative protocols, prototypes, and infrastructures that enable civic engagement and interoperable civic utilities for direct governance and stewardship of our communities and commons. We see these collaborative methods and prototypes as critically underfunded force multipliers for multi-agent coordination on key systemic leverage points that create deep social change. 

Ideal applicants will be engaged in developing technology, applied research, and social processes related to collaboration and coordination for collective action. Projects may address the diverse stack of collaborative protocols needed for successful multi-agent coordination such as: identity and attestation, on-chain delegation and roles, decentralized project management, fundraising and allocation, systems-aware strategic alignment processes, measurement and evaluation, and participatory governance and learning. These efforts may be theoretical and research-based or may be applied contexts of collaboration whose successful actualization could lead to protocolization of key activities and collaborative functions.  

For additional definitions and application details, please visit https://go.opencivics.co/wiki

questions.query: Please describe how your project contributes to the growth and development of the Octant ecosystem.
questions.explanation:
Octant aims to become the first self-sustaining global public goods funding ecosystem that balances the common good and individual financial empowerment.

LexClinic aims to be a charity that furthers the goal of law is a public good and is working with network state zuzalu-inspired nodes around the world to establish a network of terra firma dependent and terra firma transcendent enclaves, recognizing how much the EVM settlement layers have already balanced common good with financial empowerment.

questions.query: How does your project align with the round's focus on community and education within the Octant ecosystem?
questions.explanation: The Clinic is a community of patrons, some lawyers and law students some entrepreneurs, educating people about web3 law.

questions.query: Provide a clear roadmap of your project, detailing future milestones and deliverables. How does this demonstrate your commitment to long-term impact and growth within the Octant ecosystem?
questions.explanation: Get 501(c)3 status. Get 5 more entities 501(c)3 status within 1 year (already got 5 entities that status), streamline the become a patron to be listed on Endaoment pipeline in 1 year, get the journal of legal engineering published in time for Vitalia Safe Harbor II in november.

questions.query: Describe your team's expertise and how it contributes to the successful execution of your project.
questions.explanation: Our senior associate at Ixian.tech is running the Clinic's admin and is very knowledgeable in the law, our partnership with law firms is critical to getting our Patron legal services including pro bono, I am working with senior students at TSU law to bring their student body into the clinic. More at https://giveth.io/project/lexclinic .

questions.query: How does your project complement or enhance existing initiatives within the Octant ecosystem rather than competing directly against them?
questions.explanation: Legal templates, improving general legal knowledge.

questions.query: Describe your approach to community engagement and how you plan to contribute to a collaborative and constructive funding environment.
questions.explanation: Patrons buy annual membership and can learn together about the law. Improve the 501(c)3 process and getting a non-profit entity ready to go. Grants from other sources like Endaoment.

questions.query: How do you plan to use the funding to maximize your project's ongoing impact within the Octant ecosystem if selected?
questions.explanation: Pay students and administrators reasonable wages. Develop out the inverted precedent system described here https://drive.google.com/file/d/1nplI7RB3Z9c8vOA2GG7Yo0poNDKOLMTl/view

questions.query: What unique educational content or resources have you created for the Octant ecosystem? How has the community received these? Please share any relevant links
questions.explanation: We have templates and plan to build out more https://github.com/lexclinic/Templates , our legal risk checklist we go through with Patrons, articles in the Journal of Legal Engineering when it's ready.

questions.query: Describe any pioneering development work in your project, particularly in enhancing privacy, interoperability, or user experience.
questions.explanation: Working with coordination.network and as a devcon legal scholar to take the large body of crypto law and make easy to understand chat AI quizzes for public legal education out of them.

questions.query: What specific problems or challenges in the Ethereum ecosystem does your project address? How does your solution improve upon existing alternatives?
questions.explanation: Law for public good. Right now, our ecosystem views law as against public good, and that's for good reason.

questions.query: Outline your project's roadmap and how the grant funds will be used to achieve your development goals.
questions.explanation: Continue to help Web3 projects become public goods. See details at https://giveth.io/project/lexclinic .

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the decentralization and security of the Ethereum network?
questions.explanation: At ZuVillage, I began building out the narrative that there is law that transcends nations. This law is very narrow, but it now exists because of an uncaptureable world computer that runs on smart contract incentives.

questions.query: How does your project contribute significantly to the Ethereum network's infrastructure? Please provide specific examples and metrics if available.
questions.explanation: We're building out 'sovtec.eth' (the sovereignty tech meta-category we invented) by running legal engineering in many of the Zuzalu popups, such as at ZuVillage. We are deeply involved in the network state movement through or leadership in Prospera. We're developing Hats Protocol's legal utility value too, and are one of the top protoDAO token holders.

questions.query: Describe any pioneering development work in your project, particularly in enhancing privacy, interoperability, or user experience.
questions.explanation: Smart contracts and Ricardian agreements were both invented in the late 90s, and hypothetically complement each other well. At the Clinic, we're finally figuring out how to do that practically using Hats Protocol for Ricardian Networks, more granular than Ricardian contracts because we can chain the Hats together. Compare the first DAO solution, that uses often poorly fitting legal wrappers and that's it.

questions.query: What specific problems or challenges in the Ethereum ecosystem does your project address? How does your solution improve upon existing alternatives?
questions.explanation: Combining legalese and smart contracts. So that we can move beyond the legal wrapper era. A FLOSS alternative to MetaLeX or at least with other priorities.

questions.query: Outline your project's roadmap and how the grant funds will be used to achieve your development goals.
questions.explanation: We will use the grant for operational costs and the cost of advertising the Clinic during GG23. If the grant is larger than normal, then we will use it to help us finally transition to the beta stage. Our biggest operational costs are running our office hours, which anyone can attend by visiting https://lex.clinic/resources-public-page-43294049403862367

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the decentralization and security of the Ethereum network?
questions.explanation: Decentralization is woowoo that keeps us from engineering actual solutions. Our project is here in part to get people to think about disintermediation and polycentric, for instance the polycentric law that LexClinic gets to play with in Prospera Network State / Coordi-Nation. We are also, via the templates on our Github, For instance, our agreement here, FLOSS to be used with a Hats Protocol Ricardian pattern, anticipates and manages liabilities unique to web3 that likely nobody else has yet imagined https://github.com/lexclinic/Templates/blob/main/Entry%20Agreement.md .
